channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [CASSANDRA-8248] Possible memory leak
item.description:
Sometimes during repair cassandra starts to consume more memory than expected.

Total amount of data on node is about 20GB.
Size of the data directory is 66GC because of snapshots.

Top reports: 

  PID USER      PR  NI  VIRT  RES  SHR S %CPU %MEM    TIME+  COMMAND
15724 loadbase  20   0  493g  55g  44g S   28 44.2   4043:24 java

At the /proc/15724/maps there are a lot of deleted file maps

7f63a6102000-7f63a6332000 r--s 00000000 08:21 9442763 /ssd/cassandra/data/iss/feedback_history-d32bc7e048c011e49b989bc3e8a5a440/iss-feedback_history-tmplink-ka-328671-Index.db (deleted)
7f63a6332000-7f63a6562000 r--s 00000000 08:21 9442763 /ssd/cassandra/data/iss/feedback_history-d32bc7e048c011e49b989bc3e8a5a440/iss-feedback_history-tmplink-ka-328671-Index.db (deleted)

$ sudo grep deleted /proc/15724/maps | wc -l
640118

$ sudo grep -v deleted /proc/15724/maps | wc -l
303340

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: Repair is an expensive process. After repair has completed and the JVM has garbage collected, what are you seeing? If things return to expected resource use, this sounds like expected behavior.

No, it doesn't return to expected resources after forcing GC.

Just in case:

tpstats:

Pool Name Active Pending Completed Blocked All time blocked
CounterMutationStage 0 0 0 0 0
ReadStage 0 0 6868466 0 0
RequestResponseStage 0 0 408799535 0 0
MutationStage 0 0 198570382 0 0
ReadRepairStage 0 0 46197 0 0
GossipStage 0 0 2150908 0 0
CacheCleanupExecutor 0 0 0 0 0
MigrationStage 0 0 126 0 0
ValidationExecutor 0 0 72747 0 0
MemtableReclaimMemory 0 0 97987 0 0
InternalResponseStage 0 0 41583 0 0
AntiEntropyStage 0 0 630829 0 0
MiscStage 0 0 0 0 0
CommitLogArchiver 0 0 0 0 0
MemtableFlushWriter 0 0 97987 0 0
PendingRangeCalculator 0 0 62 0 0
MemtablePostFlush 0 0 191444 0 0
CompactionExecutor 0 0 4131622 0 0
AntiEntropySessions 0 0 512 0 0
HintedHandoff 0 0 421 0 0

Message type Dropped
RANGE_SLICE 0
READ_REPAIR 0
PAGED_RANGE 0
BINARY 0
READ 0
MUTATION 30193
_TRACE 0
REQUEST_RESPONSE 0
COUNTER_MUTATION 0

compactionstats:

pending tasks: 0
Active compaction remaining time : n/a

GC was just finished:

INFO [Service Thread] 2014-11-06 21:25:05,233 GCInspector.java:88 - ConcurrentMarkSweep GC in 15275ms. CMS Old Gen: 3596661592 -> 3596726792; Par Eden Space: 1371921168 -> 0;

It still uses ~51g of RAM.

Anything interesting in thread and heap dumps? If you are only looking at the value top gives you, your initial post had 55G resident - you just posted 51G (assume this to also be resident). I don't see where the leak is.
How much physical RAM is in the machine and what are your heap configs?

Host is 48GB ram. Our linux kernel specialist now investigates why res is reported to be 51GB (main theory is that it's a rounding error). I hope he will be able to collect more details about this problem.

Xmx is 8GB.

It looks like a lot of already removed sstable files are kept mmaped. Actually it's not a memory leak, but mmaped inodes won't be removed from disk, so it's a file space leak.

Alex, have you determined the issue with resident being larger, and are you still seeing this problem? If there are any further details you can provide (are you carrying out incremental repairs? do compactions have any affect?), they would be much appreciated.

Just so we don't have two conversations on the same topic, please add comments/notes to CASSANDRA-8061 - these tickets have been linked, and that ticket has a bit more info. I'm going to add the thread dump from here to 8061 as well. Thanks!
Attaching patch that releases references to SSTR during SSTableWriter.openEarly if there's trouble. See discussion on CASSANDRA-8061 - this came up during inspection and could lead to leaks.

I was also facing the same issue, as whole 64 G memory was getting consumed by cassandra. Some one suggested me to apply this patch . After applying it now i am noticing below error very frequently in my system.log. Please help in analyzing it.

rahul.bhardwaj: Are you seeing a large number of tmplink files accumulate on your filesystem after compaction completes which led you to applying this patch? As mentioned in CASSANDRA-8061, it's unlikely the posted patch on this ticket fixes the tmplink file issue but rather addresses a potential handle/memory leak.

We don't check for 0 size memory on deserialize in OffHeapBitset so it's possible you have a corrupt BloomFilter that's 0 size. It'll deserialize and read in as 0 and then fail on assertion when it comes time to close the file. A nodetool scrub against the problematic column family may help expose that.

In general, it's probably worth adding an assertion to OffHeapBitSet and OpenBitSet's respective deserialize calls to check for 0 size and fail with an informative (i.e. point to suspect file) error.
